redox_definition.name: Redox Reaction Definition
redox_definition.formula: OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain
redox_definition.correct: In redox reactions, oxidation involves loss of electrons and reduction involves gain of electrons. These processes always occur together.

oxidation gains electrons.fix: OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
oxidation gains electrons.action: Memorise OIL RIG to remember which is which.

reduction loses electrons.fix: Reduction = gain of electrons (think: charge is reduced).
reduction loses electrons.action: The species being reduced has its oxidation state reduced.

they can occur separately.error: Electrons must go somewhere‚Äîone species loses, another gains.
they can occur separately.fix: Redox reactions always involve both oxidation AND reduction.
they can occur separately.action: If electrons are lost by one species, they must be gained by another.

persistent.action: OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain of electrons.

oxidising_reducing_agents.name: Oxidising and Reducing Agents
oxidising_reducing_agents.formula: Oxidising agent is reduced; reducing agent is oxidised
oxidising_reducing_agents.correct: An oxidising agent causes oxidation (and is itself reduced). A reducing agent causes reduction (and is itself oxidised).

oxidising agent is oxidised.error: Oxidising agent is REDUCED (it takes electrons).
oxidising agent is oxidised.fix: The oxidising agent oxidises OTHER things, but is itself reduced.
oxidising agent is oxidised.action: It gains the electrons that the other species loses.

reducing agent is reduced.error: Reducing agent is OXIDISED (it gives electrons).
reducing agent is reduced.fix: The reducing agent reduces OTHER things, but is itself oxidised.
reducing agent is reduced.action: It loses the electrons that the other species gains.

they are the same thing.fix: Oxidising agent accepts e‚Åª; reducing agent donates e‚Åª.
they are the same thing.action: One gains what the other loses.

persistent.action: The agent is named for what it DOES to others, not what happens to itself.

iodine_thiosulfate.name: Iodine-Thiosulfate Titration
iodine_thiosulfate.correct: Iodine is titrated with sodium thiosulfate. The iodine is reduced to iodide, and thiosulfate is oxidised to tetrathionate. Starch indicator turns blue with I‚ÇÇ.

thiosulfate is reduced.fix: S‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ¬≤‚Åª ‚Üí S‚ÇÑO‚ÇÜ¬≤‚Åª involves oxidation of sulfur.
thiosulfate is reduced.action: Thiosulfate is the reducing agent; iodine is the oxidising agent.

iodine is oxidised.action: Iodine gains electrons, so it's reduced.

endpoint is red.fix: Blue colour disappears at endpoint (all I‚ÇÇ reacted).
endpoint is red.action: Add starch near endpoint; titrate until blue disappears.

persistent.action: I‚ÇÇ (oxidising agent, gets reduced) + S‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ¬≤‚Åª (reducing agent, gets oxidised).

vitamin_c_oxidation.name: Vitamin C as a Reducing Agent
vitamin_c_oxidation.correct: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a reducing agent. It is oxidised to dehydroascorbic acid, losing 2 electrons. It can reduce iodine to iodide.

vitamin C is an oxidising agent.error: Vitamin C is a REDUCING agent (antioxidant).
vitamin C is an oxidising agent.fix: It donates electrons, so it's a reducing agent.
vitamin C is an oxidising agent.action: Antioxidants = reducing agents (they get oxidised instead).

vitamin C is reduced during analysis.error: Vitamin C is OXIDISED during analysis.
vitamin C is reduced during analysis.fix: It loses electrons to the oxidising agent (like I‚ÇÇ).

vitamin C doesn't react with iodine.error: Vitamin C reduces iodine to iodide.
vitamin C doesn't react with iodine.fix: This reaction is the basis of vitamin C titrations.

persistent.action: Vitamin C = antioxidant = reducing agent = gets oxidised.

endpoint_detection.name: Endpoint Detection
endpoint_detection.correct: The endpoint is detected by a colour change. In iodine titrations, starch indicator gives a blue-black colour with excess iodine, which disappears at the endpoint.

endpoint is when bubbles form.error: No gas is produced in these reactions.
endpoint is when bubbles form.fix: Endpoint is detected by colour change, not gas.
endpoint is when bubbles form.action: Watch for the colour change, not physical changes.

add indicator at the start.error: Add starch indicator near the endpoint for best results.
add indicator at the start.fix: Adding starch too early can cause it to decompose or slow the reaction.
add indicator at the start.action: Add starch when solution is pale yellow, near endpoint.

blue colour appears at endpoint.error: Blue DISAPPEARS at endpoint (all I‚ÇÇ has reacted).
blue colour appears at endpoint.fix: Blue = excess I‚ÇÇ. No blue = all I‚ÇÇ reduced to I‚Åª.
blue colour appears at endpoint.action: Titrate until the last trace of blue disappears.

persistent.gap: You don't understand endpoint detection in iodine titrations.
persistent.action: Blue (I‚ÇÇ + starch) ‚Üí colourless (no I‚ÇÇ left) = endpoint.

mole_ratio.name: Mole Ratio in Calculations
mole_ratio.correct: The mole ratio from the balanced equation is used to convert between moles of titrant and moles of analyte. This is essential for concentration calculations.

always 1:1 ratio.error: Ratio depends on the specific reaction.
always 1:1 ratio.fix: Check the balanced equation for the correct ratio.

volume ratio equals mole ratio.error: Only true if concentrations are equal.
volume ratio equals mole ratio.fix: n = cV, so ratio depends on both c and V.
volume ratio equals mole ratio.action: Use moles, not volumes, for stoichiometry.

mole ratio doesn't affect calculations.error: Mole ratio is crucial for accurate results.
mole ratio doesn't affect calculations.action: Always identify the mole ratio before calculating.

persistent.gap: You're not using mole ratios correctly.
persistent.action: Step 1: Write balanced equation. Step 2: Identify mole ratio. Step 3: Calculate.

concentration_calculation.name: Concentration Calculations
concentration_calculation.correct: Calculate moles of titrant from c√óV, use mole ratio to find moles of analyte, then calculate concentration of analyte using c = n/V.

multiply volumes to get concentration.fix: c = n/V, not c = V‚ÇÅ √ó V‚ÇÇ.
multiply volumes to get concentration.action: Find moles first, then divide by volume.

ignore dilution factors.fix: If sample was diluted, multiply final answer by dilution factor.

use mass instead of moles.fix: Convert mass to moles using M, then use stoichiometry.
use mass instead of moles.action: n = m/M, then use mole ratio.

persistent.action: Steps: n(titrant) = cV ‚Üí use ratio ‚Üí n(analyte) ‚Üí c = n/V.

sources_of_error.name: Sources of Error
sources_of_error.correct: Common errors include: overshooting the endpoint, parallax error reading burette, incomplete reaction, and oxidation of vitamin C by air before titration.

errors don't affect results.fix: Overshooting endpoint gives higher titre = higher calculated concentration.

vitamin C is stable in air.error: Vitamin C oxidises in air, especially in solution.
vitamin C is stable in air.fix: Work quickly and keep solutions fresh.
vitamin C is stable in air.action: Aged vitamin C solutions give lower results.

parallax error is negligible.error: Parallax can cause significant error in burette readings.
parallax error is negligible.fix: Read at eye level, at the bottom of the meniscus.

persistent.gap: You're not considering sources of error.
persistent.action: List errors and their effect: does each make result higher or lower?

redox_definition.title: Redox Reactions
redox_definition.content: Redox reactions involve transfer of electrons. Oxidation is loss of electrons (OIL). Reduction is gain of electrons (RIG). Both processes always occur together.

oxidising_reducing_agents.title: Oxidising and Reducing Agents
oxidising_reducing_agents.content: An oxidising agent causes oxidation and is itself reduced. A reducing agent causes reduction and is itself oxidised. Named for what they do to others.
keyPoints: Opposite of what happens to itself

vitamin_c_oxidation.title: Vitamin C as Reducing Agent
vitamin_c_oxidation.content: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is an antioxidant and reducing agent. It is oxidised during analysis, reducing I‚ÇÇ to I‚Åª.

endpoint_detection.title: Endpoint Detection
endpoint_detection.content: The endpoint is detected by colour change. Starch + I‚ÇÇ gives blue colour. At endpoint, blue disappears (all I‚ÇÇ reacted).

mole_ratio.title: Mole Ratios
mole_ratio.content: The mole ratio from the balanced equation converts between moles of titrant and analyte. Essential for accurate calculations.

concentration_calculation.title: Concentration Calculations
concentration_calculation.content: n = cV gives moles of titrant. Use mole ratio to find moles of analyte. c = n/V gives concentration of analyte.

sources_of_error.title: Sources of Error
sources_of_error.content: Common errors: overshooting endpoint, parallax reading, air oxidation of vitamin C. Minimise by good technique and fresh samples.
